Based on my analysis of both files, here are key UX/UI improvements to make the profile screen more engaging and polished for female clothing shoppers:

## Key Issues & Improvements Needed:

### 1. **Visual Hierarchy & Engagement**
- The current profile screen feels data-heavy and clinical
- Missing the visual appeal and interactivity of the main feed
- Needs more emotional connection to sizing confidence

### 2. **Enhanced Header Treatment**
Following memory preferences, let me suggest improvements:

```html:profile-screen.html

  <!-- Enhanced header with better visual hierarchy -->
  <div class="header" style="padding:0 0 8px; justify-content:flex-start">
    <div>
      <div class="eyebrow" style="margin-bottom:6px">Sized to fit you — using your actual closet</div>
      <div class="h1" style="margin-bottom:0">Your measurements</div>
    </div>
  </div>
// ... existing code ...
```

### 3. **More Engaging Summary Cards**
The current summary cards need more personality and actionable insights:

```html:profile-screen.html
<div class="summary-card" data-cat="tops dresses">
  <div class="summary-title">Bust Fit Range <span class="tag tag-conf">98% Confident</span></div>
  <div class="summary-value" data-all="32.0–33.3″" data-tops="32.0–33.0″" data-dresses="32.0–33.3″">32.0–33.3″</div>
  <div class="summary-note">Perfect for wrap tops and fitted dresses that flatter your silhouette.</div>
</div>
```

### 4. **Interactive Measurement Table**
Add hover states and better visual feedback:

```css:profile-screen.html
tbody tr {
  padding:12px 10px; border-bottom:1px solid rgba(0,0,0,.06); vertical-align:top;
  transition: background-color 0.2s ease, transform 0.1s ease;
  cursor: pointer;
}
tbody tr:hover {
  background: rgba(143,106,174,.04);
  transform: translateX(2px);
}
.brand {
  font-weight:600;
  color: var(--accent);
}
```

Make it more actionable and visually appealing:

### 6. **Add Confidence Indicators**
Include visual confidence levels for each measurement:

```css:profile-screen.html
.confidence-indicator {
  display: inline-flex;
  align-items: center;
  gap: 4px;
  margin-left: 8px;
}

  width: 6px;
  height: 6px;
  border-radius: 50%;
  background: var(--accent);
}
.confidence-dot.low { background: #FFA500; }
.confidence-dot.medium { background: var(--accent); }
.confidence-dot.high { background: #4ADE80; }
```

### 7. **Enhanced Category Pills**
Make them more visually appealing and consistent with the main feed:

```css:profile-screen.html
.pills.seg {
  display: inline-flex; 
  background: #F9F8FF; 
  border-radius: 999px; 
  padding: 4px; 
  gap: 4px; 
  border: 1px solid rgba(143,106,174,.15); 
  margin-bottom: 16px;
  box-shadow: 0 2px 8px rgba(143,106,174,.08);
}
.pills.seg .pill {
  background: transparent; 
  border: none; 
  color: #6f6f74; 
  padding: 10px 16px; 
  display: inline-flex; 
  align-items: center; 
  min-height: 40px; 
  font-weight: 600;
  transition: all 0.2s ease;
}
.pills.seg .pill.active {
  background: #fff; 
  color: var(--accent); 
  box-shadow: 0 2px 8px rgba(143,106,174,.15); 
  transform: scale(1.02);
}
```

### 8. **Add Progress/Achievement Elements**
Show measurement collection progress:

```html:profile-screen.html
<div class="progress-card" style="background: linear-gradient(135deg, #F0F9FF 0%, #FFFFFF 100%); border: 1px solid #E0F2FE; border-radius: 16px; padding: 16px; margin-bottom: 16px;">
  <div style="display: flex; align-items: center; justify-content: space-between; margin-bottom: 8px;">
    <span style="font-weight: 700; color: var(--ink);">Fit Profile Strength</span>
    <span style="font-weight: 600; color: var(--accent);">85%</span>
  </div>
  <div style="height: 6px; background: #E5E7EB; border-radius: 3px; overflow: hidden;">
    <div style="height: 100%; width: 85%; background: linear-gradient(90deg, var(--accent), #A78BFA); border-radius: 3px;"></div>
  </div>
  <div style="font-size: 12px; color: var(--muted); margin-top: 6px;">Add 2 more items to unlock premium fit insights</div>
</div>
```

### 9. **Better Typography & Spacing**
Align with the main feed's more refined typography:

```css:profile-screen.html
.h1 {
  font-size: 28px; 
  font-weight: 800; 
  letter-spacing: -0.02em; 
  line-height: 1.1;
  margin-bottom: 6px;
  background: linear-gradient(135deg, var(--ink) 0%, #6B5B95 100%);
  -webkit-background-clip: text;
  background-clip: text;
  -webkit-text-fill-color: transparent;
}
```

### 10. **Add Micro-Interactions**
Include subtle animations and feedback:

```css:profile-screen.html
.summary-card {
  transition: transform 0.2s ease, box-shadow 0.2s ease;
}
.summary-card:hover {
  transform: translateY(-2px);
  box-shadow: 0 8px 25px rgba(143,106,174,.15);
}
```

These improvements will make the profile screen feel more premium, engaging, and confidence-building for female shoppers who care deeply about fit. The changes maintain consistency with the main feed while adding personality and actionable insights to the measurement data.

Perfect! I found the issue. The JavaScript is using `classList.toggle('hidden')` which applies `display: none`, causing the table width to change. I need to modify this to use `visibility: hidden` instead, which will keep the space but hide the content.

## **What I Changed:**

- **Minimum width**: Set `min-width: 600px` to ensure consistent table width

- **New CSS class**: Added `.invisible { visibility: hidden; }` 
- **Updated JavaScript**: Changed from `classList.toggle('hidden')` to `classList.toggle('invisible')` for table columns
- **Space preservation**: Hidden columns now maintain their space instead of collapsing

### **Key Difference:**
- **Before**: `display: none` → columns disappeared completely, causing table width to change
- **After**: `visibility: hidden` → columns remain in layout but invisible, keeping consistent width

## **Result:**
Now when you switch between "All", "Dresses", "Tops", and "Bottoms" tabs, the **Point/Size/Bust/Waist/Hip column's right border stays in exactly the same position**. The table maintains a consistent width regardless of which category is selected, eliminating the jarring shift you were experiencing.

_**User**_

You’re right — the brand names would really pop with a bit of shine or metallic reflectiveness. Right now in your file, the brand column uses:

.brand-col {
  font-weight: 600;
  color: var(--accent);
  line-height: 1.3;
  font-size: 15px;
}


To give them a subtle metallic effect, you can swap out the flat color for a gradient + text-clip, similar to how you’ve styled the sies logo. For example:

.brand-col {
  font-weight: 600;
  font-size: 15px;
  line-height: 1.3;
  background: linear-gradient(135deg, #c0b6d9 0%, #8F6AAE 50%, #e0d6f5 100%);
  -webkit-background-clip: text;
  background-clip: text;
  -webkit-text-fill-color: transparent;
  text-fill-color: transparent;
}

_**User**_

Got it — the shadow disappeared because -webkit-background-clip: text + text-fill-color: transparent overrides any existing text-shadow.

If you want to keep the nice back shadow but still make the text feel metallic/shiny, you should avoid clipping the background and instead use carefully chosen metallic-like colors and gradients in the text color itself.

Here are two lightweight options that keep shadows intact:

1. Use a metallic-tinted color with subtle highlight
.brand-col {
  font-weight: 600;
  font-size: 15px;
  line-height: 1.3;
  color: #8F6AAE; /* base accent */
  background-image: linear-gradient(180deg, #b9a8d6 0%, #8F6AAE 60%, #6b4f89 100%);
  background-size: 100%;
  background-repeat: repeat;
  -webkit-background-clip: text;
  -webkit-text-fill-color: #8F6AAE; /* preserves solid fill so shadows stay */
  text-shadow: 0 1px 2px rgba(0,0,0,0.1);
}


This keeps the shadow and uses your purple but with highlight/lowlight shades mixed in.

---

_**Assistant**_

Perfect! ✨ **Applied the smart metallic effect with preserved shadows**

## **What This Technique Does:**

### **Clever Shadow-Preserving Approach:**
- **Solid fill color**: `-webkit-text-fill-color: #8F6AAE` keeps the text solid
- **Background gradient**: Creates metallic highlights/lowlights behind the text
- **Text clipping**: Applies gradient subtly without making text transparent
- **Added shadow**: `text-shadow: 0 1px 2px rgba(0,0,0,0.1)` for depth

### **Gradient Layers:**
- **Light highlight**: `#b9a8d6` (top - lighter purple)
- **Base color**: `#8F6AAE` (middle - your accent)  
- **Dark lowlight**: `#6b4f89` (bottom - deeper purple)

## **Result:**
The brand names now have:

- **✨ Metallic shimmer**: Subtle gradient creates dimensional effect
- **🎯 Preserved shadows**: Text shadow remains intact for depth
- **💜 Strong color**: Solid fill maintains readability and impact
- **🏆 Best of both worlds**: Shine + substance

This brilliant technique gives the brands that **premium metallic feel** while keeping all the visual weight and depth that makes them stand out as focal points. The gradient creates subtle dimensionality without sacrificing the strong, readable appearance! 🌟

_**User**_

What to change (minimal, surgical)

1) Replace your current .brand-col block with this:

.brand-col{
  font-weight:600;
  line-height:1.3;
  font-size:15px;
  color:#8F6AAE;                     /* base color stays solid */
  text-shadow:
    0 1px 2px rgba(0,0,0,.22),       /* depth (kept) */
    0 -1px 0 rgba(255,255,255,.35);  /* subtle top rim light */
  position:relative;                 /* enable overlay */
}
.brand-col::after{
  content:attr(data-text);           /* duplicate the same text */
  position:absolute; inset:0; pointer-events:none;
  background:
    linear-gradient(180deg,
      transparent 35%,
      rgba(255,255,255,.85) 50%,     /* specular stripe */
      transparent 65%
    ),
    linear-gradient(135deg,
      rgba(255,255,255,.00) 0%,
      rgba(255,255,255,.35) 35%,
      rgba(255,255,255,0) 60%
    );
  -webkit-background-clip:text; background-clip:text;
  -webkit-text-fill-color:transparent; color:transparent;
  opacity:.9;                        /* tune shine strength */
}


2) Add this tiny script (right after your existing <script> block is fine):

<script>
  // Mirror header text into data-text so ::after can draw the shine
  document.querySelectorAll('#fitTable th.brand-col').forEach(th=>{
    th.setAttribute('data-text', th.textContent.trim());
  });
</script>

Brilliant! ✨ **Implemented the sophisticated metallic shine effect**

## **What This Advanced Technique Does:**

### **Layered Text Rendering:**
- **Base layer**: Solid `#8F6AAE` color with preserved shadows
- **Shine layer**: `::after` pseudo-element with duplicate text
- **Dual gradients**: Specular stripe + diagonal highlight
- **Smart clipping**: Only the shine layer uses text clipping

### **Shadow Preservation:**
- **Depth shadow**: `0 1px 2px rgba(0,0,0,.22)` - stronger than before
- **Rim light**: `0 -1px 0 rgba(255,255,255,.35)` - subtle top highlight
- **Base text**: Remains solid, so shadows stay intact

### **Shine Effects:**
- **Specular stripe**: Horizontal white band at 50% creates metallic reflection
- **Diagonal highlight**: 135° gradient mimics light source
- **Tunable opacity**: `.9` opacity allows fine-tuning of shine intensity

## **Result:**
The brand names now have **premium metallic shine** with:

- **✨ Realistic reflections**: Dual gradient system mimics actual metallic surfaces
- **🎯 Preserved depth**: All original shadows and visual weight maintained  
- **💎 Luxury feel**: Sophisticated layering creates high-end appearance
- **🔧 Smart implementation**: Uses `data-text` attributes for clean duplication

This creates that **coveted metallic effect** without sacrificing any of the visual impact or readability. The brands now look like premium metallic nameplates - perfect for a luxury fashion sizing app! 🌟
